Investment Strategy

Investing in the Data Center Stack üîå

A detailed breakdown of our investment strategy, designed to capitalize on the generational infrastructure build-out powering the AI revolution.

Our High-Level Strategy & Rationale

The core investment thesis is that the Artificial Intelligence (AI) revolution is fundamentally an industrial revolution for the digital age, predicated on a massive, generational build-out of tangible infrastructure. Value is shifting from the application layer to the physical infrastructure layer: the data centers that house, power, and cool the compute. This creates a compelling entry point for long-term investors targeting a 7- to 10-year investment horizon.

  • AI Capital Expenditure Supercycle: Hyperscalers (Microsoft, Amazon, Google) are projected to surge their combined annual CapEx from $230 billion in 2024 to $500 billion by 2027, overwhelmingly directed at the Data Center Stack.
  • High-Density Compute Shift: The move from CPUs to power-hungry GPUs for AI workloads is making legacy data centers obsolete, forcing a generational upgrade cycle focused on power and cooling.

Timelines & Execution

Deployment (Years 1-2): Deploy capital into key pure-play leaders to capture momentum from strong order backlogs driven by the hyperscaler CapEx supercycle.

Maturation (Years 3-7): Hold through the infrastructure build-out and technology adoption "J-Curve", capturing value from margin expansion, pricing power, and the "second wave" of broader enterprise adoption.

The Three Pillars: Investing Across the Stack

Compute & Server Layer

High-Growth Engine

Exposure to the high-performance, application-optimized servers that are the engine of the AI revolution. This is the highest beta segment of the stack.

Power & Cooling Layer

Critical Enabler

Investment in the mission-critical infrastructure that solves the thermal and power bottlenecks created by AI, particularly advanced liquid cooling.

Facilities & Operations

Wide-Moat Foundation

Exposure to the physical data center real estate and interconnection platforms, providing stable, recurring revenue and benefiting from network effects.

Suggested Asset Allocation

Investment Ticker Category Target Allocation
Super Micro Computer NASDAQ:SMCI Compute & Servers 30% - 40%
Vertiv NYSE:VRT Power & Cooling 30% - 40%
Equinix NASDAQ:EQIX Facilities & Operations 20% - 30%

Note: Allocation bands provide flexibility. The total portfolio allocation should sum to 100%.

Prime Investment Candidates

Compute & Servers

Super Micro Computer (SMCI)

The most direct, high-beta pure-play on the AI compute build-out, with a durable moat in speed-to-market.

Investment Thesis:

SMCI's modular "Building Block" approach and close engineering ties to NVIDIA allow it to bring AI-optimized servers to market faster than competitors. As AI hardware cycles compress, this speed becomes a critical advantage. The company is perfectly positioned to capture market share as demand shifts to customized, liquid-cooled server designs.

Power & Cooling

Vertiv (VRT)

The premier pure-play on the "power and physics" bottleneck of the AI revolution and a leader in liquid cooling.

Investment Thesis:

As AI drives rack power densities beyond the limits of air cooling, Vertiv's leadership in advanced liquid cooling and high-density power distribution becomes a critical enabling technology. Its ability to deliver integrated, prefabricated modular solutions addresses the hyperscalers' need for deployment speed, elevating it from a supplier to a mission-critical partner.

Facilities & Operations

Equinix (EQIX)

A high-quality, wide-moat REIT with an unrivaled global interconnection ecosystem, providing a durable platform play.

Investment Thesis:

Equinix's moat is its powerful network effect; it facilitates more interconnections than its next 10 competitors combined. As AI workloads become more distributed (hybrid/multi-cloud), the need for secure, low-latency interconnection will grow. EQIX is the prime beneficiary of this next phase of enterprise AI adoption, offering a stable, recurring revenue model.

Predicted Performance Scenarios

Select a market scenario to view the projected performance for each asset, based on the pace of AI adoption and infrastructure build-out.

Bear Case: "The Physical Ceiling" (25% Probability)

Assumptions: The AI CapEx cycle peaks and decelerates sharply as hyperscalers fail to see tangible ROI. Power grid constraints prove insurmountable, leading to widespread project delays. A glut of "stranded" data center capacity emerges, built for an AI adoption level that fails to materialize, leading to price wars and write-downs. Implied revenue growth for stack leaders turns to low single digits or negative.

Neutral Case: "The Bifurcated Build-Out" (50% Probability)

Assumptions: The CapEx cycle continues at a moderate, sustainable pace. A clear bifurcation emerges: hyperscalers continue building high-density, liquid-cooled facilities, driving strong growth for leaders like SMCI and VRT. The broader enterprise market is slower to upgrade. Power constraints are significant but managed. Implied revenue growth for stack leaders is in the mid-to-high teens.

Bull Case: "The Digital Industrial Revolution" (25% Probability)

Assumptions: The AI productivity boom materializes across the economy, validating the massive infrastructure investment. A "second wave" of demand emerges as enterprises rush to modernize their own data centers. Breakthroughs in cooling and modular design, coupled with accelerated grid investment, allow for a rapid global build-out. Implied revenue CAGR for stack leaders exceeds 25%.

Navigating the Headwinds: Key Risks

Power Availability & Cost

This is the primary threat. A lack of access to sufficient, affordable power can halt development, strand assets, and cap growth. This is the ultimate physical bottleneck to the entire thesis.

AI CapEx Deceleration

A sharp pullback in spending from hyperscalers, due to a failure to monetize AI investments, would lead to a severe drop-off in orders for infrastructure and is a major near-term risk.

Geopolitical Supply Chain

The supply chain for critical components, particularly advanced semiconductors from Taiwan, is highly concentrated and vulnerable to geopolitical disruption, which could halt hardware production.

Regulatory & Community Pushback

Data centers' massive power and water consumption is leading to increasing scrutiny from regulators and opposition from local communities, which can delay or block new projects entirely.
